My associate and I want only to help rebuild and restore the Silver Bazaar to her former glory. Unfortunately, several of the local residents continue to refuse our generous offers to purchase their property.
Cargo bound for the holds, check. Cargo bound for Ul'dah, check. Cargo bound for the camps, check. Cargo bound for... Gods, what I'd give for a vacation!
Welcome to Scorpion Crossing, friend. The finest waypoint in Thanalan, if I do say so myself.
column23: Goods from Vesper Bay pass through here on the way to Ul'dah and elsewhere. Sadly, there are far too many crates to haul, and far too few hands to haul them.

column22: You're a good boy. Yes, you are. Oh, yes, you are! Who hauled that cargo all the way here? My good boy did. Oh, yes, he did! Here's some water and gysahl greens for my good boy.
Keep yer hands where me eyes can see, 'venturer. There'll be no thievin' in the Crossin' on me watch.
This lovely little seaside hamlet is the Silver Bazaar, and this lovely little lady you see before you is Kikipu.
column23: Hey! What are you looking around for? <Emphasis>Me</Emphasis>, you idiot! I'm Kikipu!

column22: There've been more and more people come to Ul'dah since the Calamity. The hammers are pounding the ground solid so as to make it fit for new homes for the rich.
column23: I hear they're having trouble securing some tracts, though. Whoever's job that is, I don't envy them.

column22: Kweeeh!
We Brass Blades will lay our lives down for the safety of Horizon!
What the hells am I to do with three crates of vanya silk gloves─all <Emphasis>left-handed</Emphasis>!? If I can't find a buyer by next moon, I'm <Emphasis>ruined</Emphasis>!
Finest imported wares, straight from the ship's hold to you! Not even in Ul'dah will you find such a wide selection!
This never-ending procession of merchants will be the death of me. There must be an easier way to make an honest gil─say, fighting wild beasts in the Coliseum, or some such.
They say the mines nearby have been overrun by wild beasts. All I know is it will be murder on my business if the miners stop showing up.
Some thaumaturge elite have been poking around the ruins. Waste of time if you ask me.
column23: But to each his own, I suppose. So long as they don't get in the way of us doing <Emphasis>real</Emphasis> work!

column22: Can't ye see I'm on watch here? Now piss off 'fore I have ye locked up!
Mendin' nets is the first work of any fishwife. The nets are always gettin' torn on rocks and coral, and pullin' up all manner of rubbish besides.
Our cove is shaped as the moon when it first waxes and last wanes. It's from there our village takes the name Crescent Cove.
column23: Times were good here...until the Calamity befell. Now the waters flow in ways they didn't, fish no longer are where they were, and hauls are too scarce to make it worth the while.

column22: <sigh> What's the bleedin' point anymore? Anything I fish up, the bandits carry off! I'm better off just layin' down and dyin'.
Please, <If(PlayerParameter(4))>ma'am<Else/>sir</If>, don't mind my brother. He doesn't mean what he says. He's touched, you see, and─
column23: Oh, you're an adventurer. I thought you were one of the bandits. Gods forbid they hear the things my brother says about them.

column22: I ain't afraid o' no bleedin' bandits! If I could just get my hands on a good blade, I'd get rid of 'em myself, I would!
You've the unfortunate displeasure of being in Lost Hope. The name says it all, friend. You'll find naught but hunger and despair here.
I used to have a great post in the city markets. Then one day, my supervising officer decides he doesn't like the arrangement I had with the merchants.
column23: Long story short, they sent me here to <Emphasis>protect</Emphasis> this humble settlement, along with Leofric. And here we shall remain─until we die or resign, whichever comes first.

column22: Despite havin' no decent soil, we've managed to grow some crops. The wee ones can enjoy a proper meal on occasion.
I'd leave here this very day if I could, but I haven't the gil to do so. And gods know there's no work to be had in this stagnant cesspit.
Ever visited the Sagolii Desert? 'Tis an incredible sight─a godsdamned ocean o' sand, stretchin' from horizon to horizon.
column23: Shame that gettin' there ain't easier. Ye've got to pass through Zanr'ak, an' that's a good way to get yerself slaughtered by the Amalj'aa an' other foul beasties.

column22: The Amalj'aa prowl the lands to the south. Venture not into their territory unless you are well prepared.
column23: Life is a gift, adventurer. See that you do not squander yours.

column22: Did you ever wonder <Emphasis>why</Emphasis> the Pugilists' Guild is found next to the Platinum Mirage? The casino hires the members to watch over their elite clientele.
column23: But not to keep them. No, they are there to see to it the wealthy patrons do not cheat the house.

column22: This is the Gate of the Sultana. It was erected to commemorate the ascension of Her Majesty Nanamo Ul Namo to the throne.
column23: Ul'dah's future is bright indeed, so long as it is under her rule.

column22: Try not to become too engrossed in shopping, adventurer. While you haggle over some overpriced curiosity, a cutpurse might be eyeing you.
Every man, woman, and child in Ul'dah knows the names of the great Coliseum champions.
column23: The Bull of Ala Mhigo, the Hellfire Phoenix, the Twin Swords of Nald'thal...
column24: And one day, me─the Garnet Gladiator!

column22: Why hasn't she come yet? Is there...another man? No... She wouldn't. She <Emphasis>couldn't</Emphasis>. Not her... Not my...
column23: Yelloooooow Moooooon!!!

column22: Minin's as much about restin' as it is about workin'. That is to say, a hard day's labor demands a hard night's drinkin'.
No, no, no! This doesn't match at all! Oh, I can't let him see me like this. What's a girl to do?
I once dreamed I was buying all the latest fashions at Sunsilk Tapestries─gowns of silk and goldspun and ermine. But life has killed the dream I dreamed.
I can't wait to see what magnificent designs the weavers will produce next! Just look at the variety of fabrics at their disposal!
All of Eorzea foams at the mouth whenever a new Sunsilk design is revealed. My colleagues and I are always under enormous pressure.
I fancy myself a man of distinguishing tastes, and I can tell you with all certainty that the quality of Ul'dahn garments is unmatched. There are simply none finer.
Redolent Rose is master of the Weavers' Guild. His work is true genius. Bold yet delicate, traditional yet innovative. There is none more fit for the job than he.
All these pretty people in their fancy clothes. <sigh> Fanciest thing I've ever worn is this suit of mail, which─<sniff> <sniff>─is beginnin' to smell...
Beyond lies the upper tier of Ul'dah, home to nobles and aristocrats alike. Know that here the eyes of the Sultansworn are upon you at all times.
The royals strut about as though the sun shone out of their arses, but I hear life in the palace isn't nearly so sweet as they'd have us believe.
column23: Word is most merchants lead far fatter lives than any of the sultansblood.

column22: Time was, the Sultansworn were the finest warriors in Ul'dah. But they've since grown as feeble and flaccid as the royal family itself.
column23: <spit> Hells, they'll not even be a match for the Brass Blades before long.

column22: We Sultansworn have vowed to put the safety of the sultana and her house before all else! But I sure could go for a sandwich...
Ahem... Speaking of colors, though... The fountain and plaza below are known as the Gold Court. In former days, many a royal gala graced its stones.
<sigh> Just mentioning the treacherous heat causes fatigue... And my passion for alchemy is such that I oft forget to sleep.
column23: And so I have resolved to concoct a magical elixir─a potable that shall imbue the imbiber with the energy of a bull, red with waking rage! Sleep, begone!

column22: It's been months since I've joined the guild, yet they've taught me only the most basic alchemy.
column23: It's possible that seeing only my own questionable alchemical concoctions has influenced my taste in color palettes...

column22: I realize what it looks like to the untrained eye. No more than making medicine, day in and day out, right? But what if I told you I mix dyes as well? No, I...I suppose that's just as boring.
I've dined at many of Ul'dah's finer establishments, but none hold a candle to the Quicksand.
column23: Somehow the ale tastes sweeter when drunk in her presence...

column22: The Seat of the First Bow lies beyond.
None but authorized personnel may enter.
I happen to be heading across the lake to Sweetbloom Pier in the East Shroud.

I've been running the ferry to Sweetbloom Pier since back before the Calamity. I remember when the East Shroud used to be a quiet, peaceful place, but now it is crawling with all sorts of terrible creatures.
column23: I couldn't sleep at night knowing I'd left a poor, young <If(PlayerParameter(4))>miss<Else/>lad</If> such as yourself on the opposite bank only to be gored by some ravenous boar. How about you add some notches to that there belt of yours, and then we'll see about taking you across?
column24: This ferry will become available upon reaching level 10.

column22: I was just about to return to Old Gridania.
Every marauder goes through the same brutal trainin', an' it's that sense o' kinship what binds the guild together. I'm always willin' to go the extra malm for a fellow axe-wielder.
They say these pirates know how to swing an axe, so I've been looking for a fight to hone my own skills.
I may be here on business, but I do so enjoy visiting foreign ports. Limsa Lominsa has a character that is quite unlike that of my native Ul'dah. The lure of the exotic is indeed irresistible.
Whenever my business brings me to Limsa Lominsa, I treat my manservant to a hearty meal here at the Bismarck.
column23: 'Tis the least I can do to reward him for his excellent service. Gods know I pay the fellow little enough! Hah hah hah!

column22: The Bismarck has never been better than it is now, under Master Lyngsath's direction. Even such dishes as folk consider simple are prepared with loving attention to detail. These days, all too few establishments strive for this level of excellence.
The Bismarck prides itself on purveying the finest cuisine in all the realm, fit to grace the tables of kings and queens.
column23: Indeed, whenever foreign dignitaries come to Limsa Lominsa, our restaurant is the first to be called upon to cater for the banquet.

column22: In spite of its prestige, the Bismarck also delivers meals to the customer's door.
column23: Master Lyngsath recently introduced this service, that folk unable to secure a reservation might still enjoy our cuisine.

column22: 'Tis true what they say: you are what you eat. Sadly, most folk fail to pay due heed to their diet.
column23: I must confess to being one of them. So engrossed do I become in seeing others fed, I often go long stretches without feeding myself.

column22: From here we stand watch over the La Thagran Eastroad, which joins Limsa Lominsa with the La Noscean lowlands.
column23: La Thagran owes its name to the heroic helmsman of the legendary warship <Emphasis>Galadion</Emphasis>.

column22: With the Maelstrom overwhelmed, it falls to the Yellowjackets to hold down the fortifications.
column23: Maelstrom forces were spread thin in the first place, and that was before the Sahagin surge!

column22: Fifty years of farming have taught me the songs of the soil and the words of the wind.
column23: Now the men come in from the sea and wish to hear them. It is good to know the knowledge will not die with me.

column22: Merlwyb's forcing pirates to trade their swords for plowshares and start anew on land.
column23: Far be it from me to question the Admiral, but how can a man who has spent his entire life reaping be taught to sow?

column22: La Noscean oranges are chock-full of nutrients and are sweet-tasting to boot. They're vital to keeping scurvy at bay, too.
column23: You'd think men who'd been away at sea would appreciate the value of fresh fruit, but these villains care only for coin.

column22: No work ethic in these washed-up lackeys! Too busy living in the past to make a difference in the present.
column23: I'd hoped they'd put that pirate muscle to good use out in the fields, but I failed to reckon on their loafing pirate bones.

column22: Yon torches light the way to Seasong Grotto for souls lost at sea.
column23: The verse engraved on its memorial was first found carved into the deck of a shipwreck, and has become a favored litany among Lominsan seafarers.

column22: Shovels? Ha! The only things that shed houses now are hungover freebooters.
column23: Away from the orchards and out of the boss's sight─perfect spot for a nap.

column22: That cliff face there is known as the Descent, an' it weren't around afore the Calamity.
column23: Used to be ye could drive a wagon straight down the road, but now... Well, now we got to make use o' this great bloody scaffoldin' to haul goods up an' down. Damn nuisance, it is.

column22: The Foremast is one of the newer Yellowjacket garrisons. You think the name strange?
column23: Well, just as the foremast is found at the front of a galley, the name of our barracks is a reflection of our willingness to fight on the front lines of battle.

column22: Follow the road through the checkpoint and it will take you into Wineport.
column23: Aye, the place is famous for its wines, but that's not all you'll find up there─the Garleans have built a military base close by, so be on your guard. The De Nevelle Checkpoint serves as one of our last lines of defense should the imperial forces attempt an invasion.

column22: Used to be that these lands were covered with a blanket of wheat, and a small settlement flourished a short walk to the north of here. The ravages of the Calamity put an end to that, as you can see.
column23: Aye, they did their best to rebuild, riding the momentum of the initiative to restore the aetheryte camps, but it's as if the very life has been leeched from the ground. Few can seem to muster the enthusiasm needed to bring vitality back to this barren soil.

column22: Taken a likin' to me lighthouse, have ye? 'Twas built on the ruins of Swiftperch Tower.
column23: We call her the “Brewer's Beacon”─a fittin' name when ye consider it shines down on the ships what are pullin' into Aleport down below.

column22: The Red Rooster Stead lies to the north of here, which is why we defend this highroad.
column23: The barley and wool the Stead produces feed and clothe the people of Limsa Lominsa.

column22: The Admiral herself has seen it fit to dub our stead an exemplary model of her settlement initiative.
column23: As a Stead botanist, I attribute our success to unyielding innovation─our willingness to attempt any and all agricultural techniques at least once, no matter how counterintuitive or potentially embarrassing.

column22: As anyone who's ever raised livestock will tell you, animals feel and show emotions as deep and real as yours or mine. One need only look for the telltale signs: a fetching pose, a come-hither stare, some provocative tail-whipping... My pets never fail to show me the same love I show them.
The bulk of wool in Eorzea is shorn either here in La Noscea, or over in Coerthas.
column23: La Noscean sheep are renowned for their soft white fleece, which is nothing like that coarse rubbish they peddle up in the highlands.

column22: The dodos love the farm-fresh food so much, they're always pecking at the fences!
column23: Sometimes they'll even peck themselves free and run about. I suppose the exercise is good for them, but it's certainly not what <Emphasis>I</Emphasis> need!

column22: The Red Rooster Stead boasts the greatest harvests of the biggest and best produce in La Noscea.
column23: It needs to be picked and shipped cleanly and quickly so that it reaches market at its freshest. Anything less would be doing the growers an injustice.

column22: Eorzea spans far and wide, but nowhere will you find so many windmills as here!
column23: Harnessing the winds that blow in from the sea to grind grain and felt fleece─is it no less than sorcery?

column22: While the mill turns in perpetuity, our toils are tied to the ebb and flow of the Stead.
column23: During harvests and shearings, we rarely catch a wink.

column22: The “Grey” in “the Grey Fleet” owes to the mills' ability to withstand even the grimmest of storms.
These mills are built from the dead works and dunnage of decommissioned ships, the cloth taken from masts of the armada.
column23: Though they may no longer ride the waves, the old ship bones still remain a fleet.

column22: Slim diggings of late. I'd say we've mined her for all the ore she's got.
column23: Luckily, Naldiq & Vymelli's has signed for the lot of it. Should make for some sturdy ships.

column22: Up until about three years ago, we had crews working every ilm of these mines around the clock. The air was so thick with dust that half of them had to dig by feel. Blind iron mining, they called it. And so the name stuck.
Before the Calamity gouged out a ravine here, this used to be one long, unbroken peninsula.
column23: 'Course, seein' as the Moraby Drydocks are on the side opposite the city, construction on the bridge went forward soon as ye could blink. It ain't quite done yet, but the Embrace is sturdy enough for fully laden wagons to trundle across.

column22: The retired pirates are a restless bunch. All day they're at it─swearing and shouting and punching and kicking, wasting all that time and energy on everything but farming.
All the local cargo companies banded together to launch this grand operation ye see afore ye.
column23: Now, it might be as they cooperated to get things rollin', but ye can wager yer grandma's wooden teeth that they'll steal each other's clients soon as sneeze.

column22: A miller takes special pride in his mill, and I couldn't be prouder of this one.
Ah, the sea breezes of Limsa Lominsa are so refreshing. Quite a dramatic difference from the sultry winds of Ul'dah. Ah, but I must remain detached. Focused.
column23: I am here, you see, to survey the extent of the Calamity's damage, but I often find myself overwhelmed by the unfamiliar sensations of this barbaric-yet-fascinating city.

column22: Due to ongoing reconstruction, demand for guild steel has never been higher. Be that as it may, the forgemasters cannot expect to maintain record profits without effort.
column23: If Naldiq & Vymelli's is to remain successful for decades to come, they must ever pursue new markets abroad. Alas, prosperity can dull a man's wits just as well as a stiff drink.

column22: It is true that a powerful rivalry exists betwixt armorers and smitties, but it is not a contest born of spite.
column23: Our guilds will soon lay aside their differences to work together on a large commission, such as, say, a warship. That's not to say there isn't the occasional squabble, of course...

column22: I've been thinking much about ships these past days. And, you know, I don't believe Limsa Lominsa would be the nation she is now without them! Could you imagine how that would affect fishing? Trade? Naval defense!?
column23: All those vessels are constructed by skilled armorers and smitties, so, if you think of Limsa as a ship, you might consider such artisans to be the sturdy keel on which the rest of the city is built.

column22: I joined the guild with the dream of following in Forgemaster H'naanza's footsteps, but every day brings another lesson in humility. Mayhap it isn't meant to be...
Well, I must admit that the variety of the catch found in Costa del Sol pales in comparison to the teeming fish markets of Limsa Lominsa.
column23: And if one were to consider the dilemmas inherent in transporting freshly caught cargo from the city, it may prove wiser to employ a fisherman directly at the manor. Do you happen to know if the guild here is willing to hire out individuals talented with line and lure?

column22: I have deemed that love and fishing are not so dissimilar in definition. Why, neither fish nor maid can be caught without a carefully considered cast, after all.
column23: But though I have spent many a season in polishing my pulls to perfection, ever are my advances avoided by the objects of my ardent affection.

column22: There ain't naught as boils me blood as the sight of an untrained whelp given free range at the forge. The work floor is akin to an armorer's battlefield, an' ye should bloody well steer clear if ye ain't got the necessary skills─yer shoddy armor's like to get some poor sod killed.
Once again, our netmaster shirks his duties to indulge in lecherous conquest! I have not the time to deal with the constant complaints from his multitude of unimpressed and irate maids!
That damn Calamity, I tell ye. I lost me wife, me son, an' me daughter-in-law in the aftermath. If it weren't fer me grandson, I don't reckon I'd 'ave much reason to linger on.
Ul'dah's come a long way since the Calamity. In the face of that terrible destruction, our people banded together to rebuild our great nation.
column23: These tracks, which stretch across Thanalan, are a testament to that resolve. Beholding them fills me with pride.

column22: The First Sword's a beauty, ain't she? But don't let her looks deceive ye─she'll cleave a man clean in half if she has a mind to do so.
Well, it is what it is. But even if there's no work to be had here, there's always a place for a man with a strong back who knows how to swing a pickaxe!
Beasts, demons, Garleans─it's a pain in the bloody arse whatever it is! How's a man supposed to feed hisself?
If you're headed to Black Brush Station, just follow the Sunway. She'll lead you there.
As commodore of the Yellowjackets, it is my duty to ensure the peace and security of Limsa Lominsa.
column23: The lives and livelihoods of her citizens are my primary concern.

column22: This is the hive of the Yellowjackets, keepers of the peace in Limsa Lominsa.
column23: We defend the commonfolk, and they serve as our eyes and ears in turn. Order is preserved under the mandate of the people.

column22: The Yellowjackets used to be part of the Knights of the Barracuda, but we were swallowed into the Maelstrom during the Calamity.
column23: Our voyage through the Maelstrom has hardened both our steel and our resolve.

column22: In the past, the Marauders' Guild weren't naught but a recruitin' house for pirate crews.
column23: That all changed once the Admiral convinced the buccaneers to sign the Galadion Accord. The guild was scoured clean of its piratical roots, an' given new leadership an' purpose.

column22: Ho there, adventurer. How fare you on the all-welcoming streets of Limsa Lominsa?
column23: Aye, the open arms of the city gather in some rough-looking sods, but under all the grime and cussing, they're basically decent folk...for the most part. You have any troubles, the Yellowjackets are here to help.

column22: I'm the hired captain of the <Emphasis>Orion</Emphasis>. She's a fine vessel, true, but a hired captain can love his ship only as much as a paid bride can love her betrothed.
column23: A ship of my own is all I've ever wanted. Was a gil away from buying one when the Calamity struck, but how can I complain when so many lost so much more?

column22: Ever wonder why this courtyard was called the Octant? It was named for the navigation tool invented by the famous Jovanni Gnonno.
column23: With the aetheryte placed here at its center, the Octant has always been one of Limsa's busiest hubs.

column22:
Pshhh... Shkohhh...
Sweetnix write many letters, but never find right words!
The east and west arms of Hawkers' Alley hold within their bustling embrace all manner of wondrous wares and exotic commodities.
column23: Our merchants keep their shelves well stocked and their prices reasonable─spend but a moment to browse the selections, and you will find much at which to marvel!

column22: This here's Hawkers' Round, where East meets West. The place bustles with buyers and sellers both.
Kyokyoroon select best selection, priceless prices for shoppers to shop! Customer's custom is truest truth!
The reopened ports got the foreign merchants flowin' in, then the merchants got the people flowin' in, an' now 'Awkers' Alley is overflowin' again!
All that would pass into Limsa Lominsa must first pass through Mealvaan's Gate. We levy excises and disallow contraband for the welfare of the market.
column23: Trade can only be free when buyers possess the necessary assurances. Without the rule of law, the streets would be overrun by traffickers and cutthroats.

column22: The Drowning Wench will always be a favorite among pirates─she's cheap, she's loaded with grog, and she never says “no.”
column23: It's been a favored haunt of adventurers for nigh on twenty years, ever since a retired freelance and his comrades established the Adventurers' Guild here.

column22:
When yer seekin' someone,♪
For a feat ye need done,♪
To the 'Venturers' Guild ye'll be callin'!♪
column23:
No deed beyond dare!♪
So long the coin be fair,♪
To their graves be the 'venturers fallin'!♪

column22: Beg your pardons, good <If(PlayerParameter(4))>madam<Else/>sir</If>, but do you have a reservation?
column23: You <Emphasis>don't</Emphasis>? My sincerest apologies, but you must book in advance to dine at the Bismarck.

column22: There's a whale of a tale behind the name of this place. Well, it's the tale of a whale, actually.
column23: Bismarck devoured all that lay in his path, and the restaurant hopes its diners will follow suit.

column22: This is the Culinarians' Guild, where the finest chefs in all the realm gather to master the culinary arts.
column23: If you are here to dine at the Bismarck, pray speak with our head waitress, H'lahono. She should be glad to assist you.

column22: Beyond the great Zephyr Gate of Limsa Lominsa lie the midlands of La Noscea.
column23: The gentle wind that passes through the gate is said to be the sweet breath of the gods, carrying life and fortune.

column22: Welcome to the heart of Limsa Lominsa─the Mizzenmast!
column23: It houses the airship landing, the Adventurers' Guild, and─at the very top─the command room of the Admiral, from where she keeps a watchful eye over Lominsan air, land, and sea.

column22: The Crow's Lift will carry you up and down the tower as fast as the crow flies.
column23: You need only speak with Grehfarr and tell him where you wish to go!

column22: What business have you with the Admiral's Lift? Tea and crumpets on the Bridge, is it? In possession of a permission paper signed by the relevant authorities, are you?
column23: The Admiral's official quarters are no place for sightseeing. If you seek the Drowning Wench, try the Crow's Lift over yonder.

column22: This is Bulwark Hall, the lowest level of the Mizzenmast. In case you aren't familiar with the nautical term, a bulwark is the plating that prevents waves from swamping a ship's decks.
column23: Replace “waves” with “hordes of howling beastmen,” and you'll get an idea of the purpose for which this chamber exists.

column22: The Kraken's Arms reach far and wide, carryin' back spices to sell at the Seventh Sage.
column23: Cap'n Carvallain watches over the business 'imself, when 'e's not busy watchin' over 'is crew.

column22: Limsa Lominsa is a place where a man's work and wits determine his worth, where an orphan can pull himself up by his bootstraps to one day lead the Kraken's Arms!
column23: If my family hadn't been murdered at sea, I'd have no doubt followed my fortune-telling father into a life of divination. Fate is a funny thing─the worst thing ever to happen to me was also the best.

column22: Without the Fishermen's Guild, the pullers wouldn't have a place to gather and discuss issues like setting a wholesale price for fish or organizing repairs for waterfront facilities.
column23: And since we started taking in foreign fisherfolk, the existence of the guild is especially important. Aside from teaching these outsiders the ways of Limsa's waters, we all get a chance to learn new tricks from one another.

column22: The lowlands of La Noscea await you on the other side of the Tempest Gate.
column23: If the Zephyr Gate is the sweet breath of the gods, then I suppose the Tempest Gate is the violent wind from the other end.

column22: And what brings ye to the Missin' Member, scrag? Think ye can just waltz in an' 'obnob with the Sanguine Sirens?
column23: Well, if yer fool enough to try, so be it. Just watch yer tongue 'round Cap'n Rhoswen! Last man that didn't? Well, 'e's a member no more, if ye catch me drift.

column22: Ye won't find no mollycoddles or ministers in my crew─just real buccaneers what know how to stand up for 'emselves!
column23: A far cry from Carvallain's band o' dandies─make no bones about it!

column22: The best godsdamned blacksmiths in the realm work these forges day and night. Every time I see 'em finish a new piece, me heart swells with pride.
column23: Plate or chain, no armor can withstand a guild-forged weapon. I'd stake me life on it.

column22: If you're lookin' to devote yourself to the art o' shapin' metal plates, then the Armorers' Guild is your temple.
column23: There ain't no sword sharp enough, or axe big enough, that we can't forge a suit of armor to protect against it.

column22: We're bound for Crescent Cove. I'll let ye come along for forty gil. Interested?
If ye like, I can take ye to the Silver Bazaar for forty gil, paid up front.
Well met, <If(PlayerParameter(4))>lass<Else/>lad</If>, and welcome to the Drownin' Wench! Consider me place yer 'ome away from 'ome.
column23: This town's famous fer lettin' any bugger in and for doin' naught to stop 'em leavin', so ye'd best get used to dealin' with free spirits.
column24: Most folk're still recoverin' from that thrice-damned Calamity, though, and are in sore need o' yer 'venturin' talents. Ye do yer best to put things to right, and I'll do me best to 'elp ye out when ye need it.

column22: Speak with Momodi inside the Quicksand. That'd be the wisest thing for you to do.
Thinking of leaving already, are you? At least have a drink at the Quicksand before you go.
I don't believe I've seen you around here before. New adventurer, am I right? Then make your way to the Quicksand and register at the guild.
Try not to get lost, adventurer. Certain parts of this city are best left unexplored.
Ye want to come along on our trip to Crescent Cove, do ye? Well, ye ain't settin' foot on my boat unless ye pay forty gil.
If ye want a ride to the Silver Bazaar, ye'll need to pay forty gil up front. If ye don't got it, then I can't do anythin' for ye.
The door is sealed tight.
Have business with Owyne, do you? Very well, you may proceed.
The Heart of the Sworn lies beyond. Only those with pertinent business are permitted to enter.
We should be happy to serve you when you have sufficient funds, <If(PlayerParameter(4))>madam<Else/>sir</If>.
We should be happy to serve you when you have sufficient funds, <If(PlayerParameter(4))>madam<Else/>sir</If>.
We should be happy to serve you when you have sufficient funds, <If(PlayerParameter(4))>madam<Else/>sir</If>.
We should be happy to serve you when you have sufficient funds, <If(PlayerParameter(4))>madam<Else/>sir</If>.
We should be happy to serve you when you have sufficient funds, <If(PlayerParameter(4))>madam<Else/>sir</If>.
<sigh> This is all I've got to show for a day's hunting. U'ralka will never let me hear the end of it.
How do you like this, adventurer? The great U'lamana is the only one among us who can bring down bigger game!
You stand before the abode of our tribe's most wise and noble chieftain. See to it that you act with propriety.
Our people live as hunters, but as we prey upon the creatures of the desert, so too do they prey upon us. Out here, the weak feed the strong─such is the law of nature.
Our tribe once dwelled here in peace, unconcerned with the affairs of the outside world. Alas, civilization encroaches ever nearer, bringing corruption and vice in its wake.
Might be as I'm doin' the teachin' now, but it only feels like yesterday that I was still droppin' my hora all over the place.
A pugilist is nothing without vigor, and few things are better for your vigor than hearty meals and lots of sleep. You could say I'm eating and sleeping my way to the top!

We gather here in great Thal's hall of worship to study the mysteries of thaumaturgy. I ask that you maintain a modicum of quietude. Hm? Oh no, not for us─we couldn't care less how loud you are. It's Priestess Mamane, you see. She's very strict about excessive noise.
Yes! Cast without constraint, my courageous colleagues! Draw on dweomers of dire and deadly destruction! Bwahahaha!
<shiver> The raw power of thaumaturgy has the potential to cause lethal devastation. Though I suppose that is what most practitioners of the art have in mind...
Hm? Judge me by my stature, do you? You'll not be so dismissive once I ensorcel you with somnolence and scrawl obscenities upon your face with demonblood ink! Hah!
The Calamity was man's doing! 'Twas our sins that brought the judgment and wrath of Azeyma! Repent, and thou shalt be showered in the Warden's light!
It's the lichyard that brings so many visitors to Camp Drybone. They come to grieve and to mourn their dead. Protect those you love, friend. It's a hard thing to see them put in the ground.

This camp lies on the road between the Black Shroud and Ul'dah. You'll find several places of note nearby. I suppose the two most well known are the Amalj'aa encampment, where the lizardmen nest, and the Church of Saint Adama Landama, where the thaumaturges tend the dead and worship Thal.
column23: Now you know why there are so many Immortal Flames and corpses about. The former keep the Amalj'aa in check, and the latter are bound to be given back to the earth.

column22: Have everything you need for a proper burial? If you find yourself wanting for aught, you'll find it at Camp Drybone!
Soon as my girl's fit for travel, we're gone. This is no place for the living...
The sun is as hot hands pressing down on you here. There's naught left of those who succumb to the heat but dry bones, hence the camp's name.
column23: I don't envy you adventurers in the slightest, what with all that gear and armor you must be carrying.

column22: The Amalj'aa worship Ifrit─a vile being they proclaim to be the Lord of the Inferno.
column23: They say whosoever looks upon him must choose one of two fates─to follow him for life or be burned to ash. Not much of a choice, if you ask me.

column22: We Immortal Flames are stationed here to keep an eye on the Amalj'aa in the region. Should you see any, do not draw too near, lest a simple grave at the lichyard await you.
This does not concern you. Please, let her grieve in peace.
Welcome to the Church of Saint Adama Landama. Our patron saint was a wealthy man in life, and so many merchants used to come calling to pray for his favor.
column23: But that all changed after the Calamity. Our small lichyard grew and grew as we took on the dead, and now we receive more mourners than merchants.

column22: As an adventurer, you are familiar with guildleves, yes? If so, you have likely seen our Saint Adama Landama, for his wealth and munificence were such that some guildleves now bear his likeness.
column23: A strange state of affairs, though, that a church bearing the name of a rich saint should now be overrun with the poor who come to bury their dead.

column22: It is my belief that this goobbue was present at the Battle of Carteneau five years ago. After its rider was struck down in battle, it sought shelter from the destruction raining down from the heavens, passing through the Twelveswood before arriving here in Thanalan.
column23: During this journey, the seeds of myriad plants came to cling to its body. Though the poor goobbue succumbed to its injuries in the end, these seeds would take root and eventually sprout from its carcass.
column24: It's amazing to see such an amalgam of species from across Eorzea. To think that such beauty could arise from that terrible tragedy... The gods do indeed work in mysterious ways.

column22: The Golden Bazaar is on the verge of unprecedented growth thanks to the mythril deposit! Mark my words, adventurer: there's billions in it! <Emphasis>Billions</Emphasis>!
There is no better time than now to be a miner. There are fortunes to be made, friend. Don't let this opportunity pass!

Pshhh... Shkohhh...
Airyself lives in objects. When full of airyself, object changes to stonyshine, name of <Emphasis>materia</Emphasis>.
Master Mutamix was an inducted brother of the Illuminati, a goblin fraternity which has long been the marvel of the scholarly world. The knowledge they possess rivals even that of the Sharlayans.

Master Mutamix belonged to a fraternity of goblin scholars known as the Illuminati, but over time found himself at odds with their secretive ways. Believing that it is through dissemination that science evolves, he betrayed his own people, taking us under his wing to pass on the secrets of materia.
If you're buying or selling, speak up. Otherwise, I've business to attend to. Next!
My administrative duties require my <Emphasis>undivided</Emphasis> attention. Do not trouble me unless we have <Emphasis>business</Emphasis> to discuss.
It's a pain in the arse checkin' every shipment out of Vesper Bay, but somebody's gotta do it. Otherwise, crates might start fallin' off the backs of the wagons, if you catch my drift.
Wait! Aren't you...? Ah, never mind. Carry on.

Halatali was abandoned following the Calamity, along with the Coliseum beasts that were raised there. The creatures have since broken free of their cages and claimed the former training grounds as their lair.

Far be it from me to brag, but the blood of explorers courses through my veins. My grandpapa drafted the first comprehensive map of Eorzea, and I've made it my life's work to revise it to reflect the changes brought about by the Calamity.
column23: To this end, I've traveled all over Eorzea, and there's nary a place in the realm I've not seen with mine own eyes. Mayhap I could direct you to some of the more interesting locales I've explored─that is, if you're not afraid of a little danger.

column22: None may enter the Fragrant Chamber without permission. I must ask that you step away from the doors, <If(PlayerParameter(4))>madam<Else/>sir</If>.
Above all else, we Gridanians value harmony. By our example, we hope to guide the realm to an age of true peace.
column23: If man and elemental can work as one, so too can the peoples of Eorzea join hands in common cause. I pray you will continue to aid us in achieving this ideal.

column22: My name is Lewin, and I lead the men and women of the Gods' Quiver. It is our duty to preserve the peace in the Twelveswood.
column23: The Ixal and the Garleans see to it that we have nary a moment's rest. As such, we always welcome the assistance of dependable adventurers such as yourself.

column22: All vessels that make use of Limsa Lominsa's ports must submit to a cargo inspection and pay the duties incurred. Please direct all inquiries and complaints to the front desk of Mealvaan's Gate.
Please, not another word! If I am ever to become an official assessor, this training exercise must be the focus of my full and undivided attention!
Cap'n Rhoswen's led the Sanguine Sirens to the top o' the food chain 'ere in Limsa. Ye want to join the meanest crew on the sea, then ye'd best bloody yer cutlass an' thicken yer 'ide.
If it is rumors or like-minded fellows you seek, then you have made the right choice in coming to this tavern. It is as a lodestone for all manner of travelers and explorers.
Our guild 'as a fine collection o' live fish in the pool there. It's always squirmin' with the latest catch, ye see.
column23: An' when the sea's been unkind with 'er bounty, I just drop a line in all sneaky-like an'─ Ahem, fine weather we're 'avin', ain't it?

column22: Are you hoping to join our crew? You'll have to walk to the back of the line and wait your turn with these others. Perhaps the captain'll like your face; perhaps he'll pitch you over the wall.
column23: There are many and more willing to risk his fickle favor for a chance to serve on Llymlaen's most beloved ship.

column22: My son has flown the nest, and I know naught of what has become of him. Each day I buy more fish than I need, that I might have a meal to feed him should he wander back through our door.
Some captains claim to 'ave the biggest, toughest pirate crews in Limsa, but no bastard makes that boast afore the gathered axes o' the Bloody Executioners.
column23: We been to the very edges o' the eastern seas, an' plucked treasures from the 'olds of imperial ships. These other scrags ain't naught but piss an' wind.

column22: The Admiral's ban on piracy has proven effective, by and large. The only problem is, the ones that refuse to give up the life are the absolute bloody worst of the lot.

It is said that the odd pillars on the Salt Strand were formed the night Bahamut's flames rained from the heavens. I am currently studying the formations to see what influence, if any, they exert on the surrounding area.
Chocobos are such sensitive creatures. Without a steady stream of care and affection, they soon fall into the blackest depression.
Have you heard the tale behind the name of this quaint little place? It all started with the birth of a rooster, feathers as red as wine. Would that the story ended there...
column23: See, the farmers laid wagers on this bird being stronger than the others, but the contest grew ugly. Blades were drawn, and both roosters and onlookers were splattered with scarlet shades of blood. Not so quaint now, eh?

column22: Most seafarers a bloke meets are rougher'n a barnacled hull, but these Lominsan scrags are somethin' else. S'pose I should expect naught less from a city what was founded by pirates.

Since I've been stationed here, I've learned more about ale than I thought possible. The folk here taught me that sailors stock barrels of the weaker stuff for long voyages, as even the freshest water will turn foul after a time.
column23: And the stronger stuff? Well, that gets bought up by the merchants visiting Aleport. Lower taxes on our local brews, you see.

column22: Why don't ye join me for a pint or two, <If(PlayerParameter(4))>lass<Else/>lad</If>? The grog's as cheap as water in this place! Even so, I reckon I've guzzled through half the sparklies I hoarded from me mercenary days, heh heh.
Adventurer wants going to shop of Jijiroon? Adventurer give forty gil!
Adventurer has no gil? Then adventurer has no go!
Adventurer wants going to shop of Memeroon? Adventurer give forty gil!
Adventurer has no gil? Then adventurer has no go!
This ferry is bound for Aleport. Are you riding with us?
I'm afraid the Aleport ferry is out of service for repairs.
column23: Until such time as she is seaworthy again, might I suggest you familiarize yourself with the amenities of our fair city, and perhaps hone your skills as an adventurer?
column24: This ferry will become available upon reaching level 15.

column22: This is the ferry fer Limsa. Ye comin' or what?
'Pologies, <If(PlayerParameter(4))>lass<Else/>mate</If>, but the Limsa ferry's out o' service.
column23: This ferry will become available upon reaching level 15.

column22: This ferry is bound for Costa del Sol. Are you riding with us?
I am afraid the Costa del Sol ferry is out of service for repairs.
column23: Until such time as she is seaworthy again, might I suggest you familiarize yourself with the amenities of our fair city, and perhaps hone your skills as an adventurer?
column24: This ferry will become available upon reaching level 30.

column22: This ferry is bound for Limsa Lominsa. Are you coming along?
I'm sorry, but the ferry for Limsa Lominsa is out of service.
column23: This ferry will become available upon reaching level 30.

column22: This ferry is bound for Aleport. Will you be traveling with us?
This ferry is bound for Candlekeep Quay. Will you be traveling with us?
You stand before the White Wolf Gate. Do you wish to exit to the Central Shroud?
You stand before the White Wolf Gate. The region beyond is rife with danger, and I am not authorized to pass untried adventurers like yourself.
The White Wolf Gate is to remain closed until further notice. If you wish to enter Gridania, you must do so by way of the Blue Badger Gate to the east.
We're going to Raincatcher Gully. Are you coming along?
We're going to Hidden Falls. Are you coming along?
This is the White Wolf Gate. Do you wish to enter Gridania?
I'm terribly sorry, <If(PlayerParameter(4))>madam<Else/>sir</If>, but our services are restricted to those who possess airship passes.
I'm terribly sorry, <If(PlayerParameter(4))>madam<Else/>sir</If>, but our services are restricted to those who possess airship passes.

I was most pleased to discover the attitude of acceptance towards beastman traders here in Limsa Lominsa. My fellow Ul'dahn merchants openly despise such savage peddlers, you see, but I believe there are opportunities being missed.
column23: The Mamool Ja, for example, are a hardy race that hail from the lands to the west, and their skill at arms is their primary export. A quality source of mercenaries, if you ask me.
column24: The bulging packs of the goblins? They often contain naught of value, but it is worth sifting through the junk for that one rare treasure. And the Qiqirn? Look no further should you wish to trade for ore or gemstones.

column22: Welcome to Candlekeep Quay. Head within and speak with the skipper if you require passage to Aleport.
column23: Used to be that only the candlekeep of Oschon's Torch made use of this port, but for a time after the Calamity struck, the Moraby Drydocks were unusable.
column24: The facilities here had to be expanded to accommodate the flood of artisans and supplies needed for the restoration efforts.

column22: You <Emphasis>have</Emphasis> heard of the Brugaire Consortium, I trust? We are one of the largest merchant outfitters in the entire city–state of Limsa Lominsa, and deal in an extensive range of wares including weapons, perishables, and fashionable apparel.
column23: I have but recently been appointed chief assistant to Vice-chairman Bango Zango. Ah, brokering deals and negotiating trade contracts...it is my calling in life.

column22: Do you seek admittance to the Lotus Stand? If so, I will show you in.
The Lotus Stand lies beyond this grove, but I cannot admit you. The Elder Seedseer is not receiving visitors at present.
Through this first mission, you will come to understand the nature of our struggle with the primals.
column23: The realm may appear well on its way to recovery, but reality paints a far bleaker picture.
column24: The truth is out there, <Split(<Highlight>ObjectParameter(1)</Highlight>, ,1)/>, and I would have you discover it for yourself.

column22: Ah, <Split(<Highlight>ObjectParameter(1)</Highlight>, ,1)/>! If you wish to head downstairs, show yourself in─I must remain here to receive any visitors that may come.
Please be advised that this is private property. Unless you have pertinent business here, I must ask you to leave.
Through this first mission, you will come to understand the nature of our struggle with the primals.
column23: The realm may appear well on its way to recovery, but reality paints a far bleaker picture.
column24: The truth is out there, <Split(<Highlight>ObjectParameter(1)</Highlight>, ,1)/>, and I would have you discover it for yourself.

column22: With the power you possess, there will be those who wish you ill, and you must needs be on the lookout for them. Yet however vigilant you are, you are but one <If(PlayerParameter(4))>woman<Else/>man</If>.
column23: In the midst of a Grand Company, however, you will be one <If(PlayerParameter(4))>woman<Else/>man</If> amongst many─a friend amongst friends. Your achievements will be shared, and so will the danger.

column22: This place is called the Waking Sands, and it's our headquarters.
column23: It used to be somewhere else, you know, but then a bunch of things happened, and we ended up here instead!

column22: This place is called the Waking Sands, and it's our headquarters.
column23: It used to be somewhere else, you know, but then a bunch of things happened, and we ended up here instead!

column22: Speeches? Oh, yes, I <Emphasis>love</Emphasis> them. There's nothing like a good exposition when you're having trouble sleeping!
While there are others who possess the Echo, none are near as strong as you with the power. Hence our <Emphasis>extremely</Emphasis> high expectations of you!
While there are others who possess the Echo, none are near as strong as you with the power. Hence our <Emphasis>extremely</Emphasis> high expectations of you!
Five years ago, the three Grand Companies joined as one and fought the Garlean Empire at the Carteneau Flats.
column23: And now, for the first time, the people will gather to remember those who fell in the battle.
column24: That being said, no one has any clear memory of what transpired that fateful day─not even the leaders of each nation.

column22: Summoning a primal is no small feat. It requires a tremendous concentration of aether, which is why the beast tribes go to such lengths to obtain crystals.
column23: Once they manifest in physical form, their unquenchable thirst for aether only grows stronger. They would drink the land dry with nary a thought to the consequences.
column24: Considering their fearsome strength, it could be well within their ability to do so. It is for this reason we must do our utmost to oppose them.

column22: Summoning a primal is no small feat. It requires a tremendous concentration of aether, which is why the beast tribes go to such lengths to obtain crystals.
column23: Once they manifest in physical form, their unquenchable thirst for aether only grows stronger. They would drink the land dry with nary a thought to the consequences.
column24: Considering their fearsome strength, it could be well within their ability to do so. It is for this reason we must do our utmost to oppose them.

column22: You've put us all to shame with your recent performance in the field. If I'm to keep up, I daresay I'll need bigger knives!

Our organization, the Scions of the Seventh Dawn, was formed through the union of two separate entities. The first was comprised of Sharlayan natives such as myself, and was called the Circle of Knowing.
column23: The second, made up of individuals that share your rare gift, was known as the Path of the Twelve.
column24: The terrible events that ushered in the Seventh Umbral Era taught us that only together may we stand against the evil that seeks to consume us.

column22: Our organization, the Scions of the Seventh Dawn, was formed through the union of two separate entities. The first was comprised of Sharlayan natives such as myself, and was called the Circle of Knowing.
column23: The second, made up of individuals that share your rare gift, was known as the Path of the Twelve.
column24: The terrible events that ushered in the Seventh Umbral Era taught us that only together may we stand against the evil that seeks to consume us.

column22: I have heard word of your deeds. I am sparing in my praise, so know that you have truly impressed me.
column23: Be that as it may, it is fortunate that Thancred arrived when he did. Had he been but a moment later, I shudder to think what may have transpired.

column22:
<Emphasis>Seven waning moons see seven suns rise,
Divine order roils, fallen corpses writhe.</Emphasis>
column23: Thus the Divine Chronicles seek to warn us once more. The meaning of these words now shines clear: they evoke the dire circumstance of this imperiled age.
column24: The realm doth shudder and twist, and the dawn lieth cowering 'neath the stifling blanket of night. And we abide. We await the coming of the unborn era's seed─the Light which shall pierce the glowering Darkness.

column22:
<Emphasis>Seven waning moons see seven suns rise,
Divine order roils, fallen corpses writhe.</Emphasis>
column23: Thus the Divine Chronicles seek to warn us once more. The meaning of these words now shines clear: they evoke the dire circumstance of this imperiled age.
column24: The realm doth shudder and twist, and the dawn lieth cowering 'neath the stifling blanket of night. And we abide. We await the coming of the unborn era's seed─the Light which shall pierce the glowering Darkness.

column22: The destruction that visited this land cannot be attributed to the forces of the Empire alone.
column23: Wyrm of midnight, of breath infernal... For some, a legend made flesh; for others, an insidious symbol of memory lost.
column24: We grasp but a piece of this puzzle. Much and more must we question and contemplate ere the fallen moon revealeth its myriad secrets.

column22: In the years before the Calamity, my organization, the Path of the Twelve, took under its wings those possessed of unique powers, that they might employ their talents for the good of the realm.
column23: Although we have since made common cause with the Circle of Knowing and taken on the name of the Scions, our objective remains the same─safeguarding the future of Eorzea.
column24: Come what may, it is my hope that this spirit shall ever live on within brave souls such as you.

column22: Let me see if I have this right─you're an adventurer...who's a Scion...<Emphasis>and</Emphasis> a <If(GreaterThan(PlayerParameter(52),0))>Storm<Else/><If(GreaterThan(PlayerParameter(53),0))>Serpent<Else/>Flame</If></If>? Golly, how do you keep track of everything?
column23:
It must be fun pairing up with lots of different people, though! Me? I'm <Emphasis>always</Emphasis> with Papalymo.
...Come to think of it, why <Emphasis>am</Emphasis> I always with Papalymo?

column22: Following the Calamity, each nation's armed forces underwent large-scale restructuring centered upon its Grand Company.
column23: In Gridania, the Order of the Twin Adder absorbed both the Wood Wailers and the Gods' Quiver, while the Lominsans enacted the complete merger of the Maelstrom and the Knights of the Barracuda.
column24: Ul'dah is the odd nation out, having made no notable changes to its armed forces. As before, and in the spirit of the sultanate, each entity retains a certain degree of independence.

column22: The incident with the traitor still weighs heavily on everyone's minds─the Flame General's most of all.
column23: And although he cannot be expected to know what evil lurks in the hearts of every man under his command, the revelation is nevertheless a devastating blow to his authority.
column24: Even so, it warrants saying that you should <Emphasis>not</Emphasis> let this tragedy color your opinion of the man. In all my years working with the Flame General, I've never had reason to doubt his capacity to lead.

column22: We will continue to focus our efforts on investigating the primals. The Amalj'aa are not the only tribe that has succeeded in summoning its deity.
Fate shall be thy guide. When our purposes become one, once again shall our paths lead us here...
column23: Our city of learning is now naught but shadows. Ere the light of dawn breaketh, shall we follow whither the sand blows.

column22: Greetings, <Split(<Highlight>ObjectParameter(1)</Highlight>, ,1)/>. If you have business with Admiral Bloefhiswyn, the Admiral's Lift stands ready to bear you aloft.
The door is sealed tight.
Come to check on me, have you? Well, you may rest assured I have found new purpose at this humble post, and I have no intention of abandoning it again.
column23: All that I have learned from my commander, I shall employ in service to the Wood Wailers and Gridania at large. 'Tis the least I can do to repay him for all he has done for me.

column22: Ever a sight for sore eyes, my friend. My thanks again for your patience with Landenel.
column23: Your presence was instrumental in helping him to let go of the past, I believe, and now he can focus on forging his own future. I look forward to seeing what he makes of himself in the years to come.

column22: When the sultan Sasagan Ul Sisigan, first of his line, founded the nation of Ul'dah, he decreed that the Royal House of Ul would ever be attended by a sworn brotherhood of elite warriors.
column23: Under Captain Jenlyns's leadership, we carry on that sacred tradition. The captain himself labors tirelessly to keep the sultana safe from those who plot against her.
column24: Alas, there are many who would welcome her fall...

column22: Limsa Lominsa is not unique in her suffering; all the nations of Eorzea struggle with a multitude of hardships.
column23: The difficulties of this age will not be surmounted without the aid of you and your fellow adventurers, thus I pray that your eagerness and compassion never wane.

column22: My loyalty goes beyond obedience. If your deeds would serve Master Gegeruju's interests, then my deeds shall serve yours.
Just because I, Bango Zango, preside as second chair over the Brugaire Consortium, does not mean I have the time to consort with all and sundry.
Sure, farm life sounds plenty splendid and all, but for some reason, I'm not quite ready to give up this drudgery.
I realize I'm a tiny fish amid a sea of sharks, but I think there are enough shrewd traders in this cutthroat market for an honest peddler to carve out a decent niche.
My <Emphasis>Ice Princess</Emphasis> is the most graceful vessel ever to glide across the open seas. The waves can spin her round and round, but she'll never fall down.
The Thaumaturges' Guild is run by five siblings. The eldest is Cocobuki, who is recognized as guildmaster. After him are Cocobygo, Cocobani, Cocobezi, and Cocoboha.
column23: Hmmm... There was a sixth sibling, though, as I recall. The youngest, who did not take the vows of the Order. But then, I am wrong from time to time.

column22: What I wouldn't give for a chance to spar with the Holyfist... Alas, he refuses me every time I ask.
column23: I know I need more training, but still! What must I do to prove myself worthy?

column22: Have you spoken with Adalberta, our guildmaster? It goes without saying that she is a skilled miner, but above all, she is a caring person who always looks after her own. I wouldn't want anyone else in charge.
Guildmaster Severian is terribly...devoted to his research. So devoted, in fact, that he oft ignores his responsibilities to the guild itself.
column23: He very well may be one of the finest alchemists in all of Eorzea, but I would that he applied his genius in a somewhat broader fashion.

column22: Although Mistress Serendipity is an acclaimed goldsmith, I fear she is still unaccustomed to the rigors of leadership.
column23: But I have faith that she will grow into her new position─so long as she avoids unnecessary distractions.

column22: There are none who wield more influence over Ul'dahn fashion than the great Redolent Rose.
column23: Every weaver in the city looks to his masterpieces for inspiration. He is, quite simply, a living legend.

column22: If you're lookin' to mingle with folk from all over, then the Quicksand is the place for you.
Hello there, adventurer! You new to town? Best direct all your questions to Mistress Momodi then─she'll take care of you.
Come, <If(PlayerParameter(4))>lass<Else/>lad</If>, is this your first visit to Ul'dah? Oh, you'll find it to be a fine city, with more chances to make gil than anywhere else!
column23: If you'd like to earn a bit yourself, best go speak to Momodi about getting started. You'll find her just behind that counter, there.

column22: City folk ought to thank us every day for our hard work. Vesper Bay may be Ul'dah's gateway to the five seas, but it's the dockmen who see that the shipments flow through it.
Welcome to the Pissed Peiste, love! Why not have a drink while ye wait for yer ship? Just don't blame us if ye forget to board it!
They say Lord Lolorito practically funded the reconstruction of Vesper Bay himself. That's why the town honored him with that humongous bronze statue.
column23: It's a bit much, though, don't you think? I'd wager he's much fatter and uglier. But, uh, that's just between you and me.

column22: Gods, each day I spend in this sorry excuse for a settlement is worse than the last. I can't wait until I've saved enough to move to Ul'dah!
You there! Yes, <Emphasis>you</Emphasis>! You were gazing at me with lustful eyes, weren't you? Don't even think to deny it!
column23: Well, I shall say to you this: you have <Emphasis>exquisite</Emphasis> taste, my dear <If(PlayerParameter(4))>woman<Else/>man</If>. I daresay you have a future in color coordination.

column22: Copperbell Mines were first opened by royal decree during the Thorne Dynasty, over three hundred years ago. However, due to the Great Giant Revolt, the mines were sealed and abandoned for centuries.
column23: The Concern purchased the mines from the royal family twenty years ago, but saw no need to resume operations until recently. Demand for ore rose sharply in the wake of the Calamity, and only fools would let developed mines go to waste─or so they thought.
column24: Should've left it all buried and forgotten, if you ask me.

column22: We of the Maelstrom do not jest when we say, “till sea swallows all.” The soldiers of our company fight until the very last breath─the very last drop of blood.
column23: Are we chained by these words? Nay, it is a freedom in which all who join our ranks learn to exult.

column22: We Immortal Flames fight to protect Ul'dah from all who would threaten her.
column23: Ever do we swear to uphold our oath: for coin and country!

column22: Heading down so soon? Best you sort out your affairs here before you start gallivanting about. I'll let you use the lift soon enough.
Newly come to Limsa Lominsa, adventurer? Then I suggest you speak with Baderon, the owner of the Drowning Wench. Think of him as a guide to our fair city.
Were you able to find the Drowning Wench? Baderon there will help get you started here in Limsa Lominsa.
Can't say I much care for the ridiculous uniforms those blokes over there at the Hall of Flames have to wear.
column23: If you fancy sporting the same blue duds, though, you could always enlist. The Immortal Flames take everyone─even foreigners.

column22: I had no idea that the Platinum Mirage was such an exclusive establishment. That they can afford to turn away wealthy individuals like myself speaks volumes.
column23: It's probably for the best, though. An old acquaintance of mine lost everything in the gambling halls. Last I heard, she had run afoul of some dangerous people─or was it that she had fallen in with them? I can't seem to recall...

column22: Did you hear? My beloved Franz is fighting today! I can't wait to see him carve that overgrown oaf into bloody chunks!
Beyond these doors lies Scholars' Walk, where you will find Frondale's Phrontistery and the Heart of the Sworn.
If I take this opportunity, will I miss out on a better one? It's all so overwhelming... Maybe I should mull it over at the Quicksand.
Oi, 'venturer! Why not spend some of that hard-earned coin here at the markets? Go on an' treat yerself! Ye <Emphasis>deserve</Emphasis> it!

Ye can get to the aetheryte by takin' the lift over to me left. Afore ye 'ead down, though, ye oughta introduce yerself to the lads an' lass 'ereabouts. Might be as they'll 'ave a juicy piece o' gossip to share with ye.
My li'l sis was the only family I had left...till the flux up and took her away, too. 'Tweren't easy, but I brung her all the way here. Now all's left is to put her to rest proper, like she deserves.
This path leads to the Minotaur Malm. If you're headed there, I will show you the way.
Nald's Reflection is through here. The way is dark, but I've walked it a thousand times. I can guide you through if you like.
Nophica's Altar is a place of contemplation. Visitors are asked to refrain from creating a disturbance.
Do you wish to leave the landing area?
Do you wish to leave the landing area?
Do you wish to leave the landing area?
Listen well. These waters feed into the marshes of Drybone. A short swim will see us to freedom.
column23: However, if all of us attempt to flee, we are like to be discovered. You alone must sneak out and assemble a rescue party.
column24: Once you have won free, seek out our comrade stationed at Drybone. He will show you the way back here. May the Twelve speed your way.

column22: You are about to be transported to the battle area for the quest “Lord of the Inferno.” This is a provisional measure for phase 3 of the beta test.

Limsa Lominsa is paradise for a culinarian, for by the grace o' the pullers, we've the bounty of the sea close at hand. Ahhh, if only there were more bells in a day─I'd buy the whole guild's catch an' cook to my heart's content!
I was born and raised to the west of here. You won't find the village on recent maps, though. The Sahagin removed any need to mark it.

Ain't but one thing ye need to succeed in life, an' that's gumption. Had not a gil to me name when I started searchin' for shells to sell, but look at me now─got me own proper business, an' I ain't had to gather shells meself in years!

Hm? Are you perchance looking to purchase fresh fish? Well, I...uh...I'm afraid I just sold the last of my stock! Very sorry, friend, but due to my reputation as a first-rate fisherwoman, my wares are quite popular!

Beg your pardon, <If(PlayerParameter(4))>madam<Else/>sir</If>, but I haven't time for idle chitchat. It is of paramount importance that I attend to Master Gegeruju's <Emphasis>every</Emphasis> whim...no matter how misguided.

With the coming of the everlasting snows, each year's harvest grows ever poorer. It falls to the Confraternity of Fisherfolk to ensure that the people of Coerthas do not want for sufficient sustenance.

I've heard many a tale of Vylbrand's shimmering waters, teeming with life innumerable and unimaginable. But in the Sea of Clouds dwell far more fantastic species, unlike anything you might find in the five seas. Take up the pole and cast a line if you doubt my words.

I fully acknowledge that we can learn much about ancient Allag by studying its people's dietary habits. Nevertheless, I would have greatly preferred that <Emphasis>anyone</Emphasis> else be given charge of this research...
Ye want to go to Crescent Cove, do you? Sorry, but the ferry's undergoin' repairs right now. Come back later, eh?
column23: This ferry will become available upon reaching level 12.

column22: Ye want a ride to the Silver Bazaar? Sorry, but we ain't makin' a trip any time soon. The ferry be needin' repairs, see.
column23: This ferry will become available upon reaching level 12.

column22: This ferry is bound for Aleport. If you want to ride with us, it'll cost you forty gil.
Headed fer Limsa? I can take ye there, but it'll cost ye forty gil.
This ferry is bound for Costa del Sol. It's forty gil if you desire passage.
This ferry is bound for Limsa Lominsa. Passage is forty gil up front.
I'm afraid that the ferry for Aleport is getting recaulked at the moment. Please come back another time.
column23: This ferry will become available upon reaching level 15.

column22: Need passage to Candlekeep Quay, do you? I'm afraid the ferry has torn a hole in its hull. Repairs will take a while yet.
column23: This ferry will become available upon reaching level 15.

column22: Passage to Aleport is forty gil. Please pay prior to boarding.
This ferry is bound for Candlekeep Quay. It's forty gil if you want to travel with us.
We're going to Raincatcher Gully. Forty gil if you want to come along.
We're going to Hidden Falls. Forty gil if you want to come along.
This skiff is bound for the Wolves' Den. Might you care to join us?
The skiff's headed back to the Moraby Drydocks. You coming along?
We're headed back to Aleport. Hop in if you like.
We're headed for the Isles of Umbra. You coming along?
I'd offer to ferry you o'er to the Isles of Umbra, but access is prohibited at the moment.
We're headed for the Isles of Umbra. Forty gil gets you a spot.
We're goin' to the Serpent's Tongue. Need a ride?
We're s'posed go to the Serpent's Tongue, but there's been some sort of incident. Ain't safe to cross right now.
We're goin' to the Serpent's Tongue. Forty gil, an' ye can ride with us.
Where there is need, there is profit. Fortunately for me and my enterprising brethren, the residents of this settlement are ever in need.

In times of relative calm, the soldiers of House Durendaire expect to receive only the best equipment. But now that all of Whitebrim Front is preparing to retake the Stone Vigil, they have desperate need for materiel, as well as individuals like me who can procure it.

To an outsider, monitoring the needs of our naturalists and requisitioning the necessary supplies may seem a dreadfully boring charge, but nothing could be further from the truth. My duties require that I stay abreast of each team's activities, which means <Emphasis>I</Emphasis> am among the first to learn of new discoveries!
S-Stay your sword! I promise, I'm not like the others. Why, I absolutely <Emphasis>despise</Emphasis> the taste of adventurer brains!
column23: Bloodthirsty adventurers, always trying to hack me limb from limb! What did we zombies ever do to them? ...Aside from the brain-eating, that is.

column22: I hate to disappoint you, maggot, but the Wolves' Den is still under construction! Ah, but never fear─soon enough we'll have plenty of need for fresh meat! Gahaha!
I realize that I am standing here expectantly, but this counter won't be open for service until the Wolves' Den is complete.
Like the looks of my wares, do you? Don't worry, it won't be long till you can lay your hands all over them.
It's taking a bit longer than expected to set up the Wolves' Den. We hope to begin operations within a few moons.
Sorry, <If(PlayerParameter(4))>lass<Else/>lad</If>, but none o' these counters're open fer service jus' yet. Come back later, eh?
When the Wolves' Den finally opens, you may come to me to be issued protectives.
Chuchuroon's mouth waters at mouthwatering fish from waters.
Never gone fishing in the desert? There's no difference between sand and sea once your quarry is on the hook.
The true test of a knight comes against the foes he cannot slay. The cold is indeed harsh, but the snows shall only serve to harden my resolve.

When I come here and look out over the Twelveswood, I can feel the elementals watching over me, protecting me. I close my eyes, open my ears to the sounds of the forest, and let all my troubles disappear.
Why, I've served Raya–O since she was a little girl no bigger than me, kupo! She has matured much since the Calamity. Her brother A–Ruhn, on the other hand...
When she was a child, Raya–O had quite a temper. She's a sweet little girl now, but a moogle does not easily forget. Even now, the sound of her voice makes my fur stand on end, kupo!
I fear entry to Milvaneth Sacrarium is forbidden for the nonce. Repairs are underway to remedy the rot and dilapidation that have spread within.
The people of this land would kill me for no more than my Amalj'aa skin. And so I must remain here, in hiding.
column23: The day will come when I shall fulfill my purpose─the destiny of both my forebears and myself. But only through patience and prudence now will I live to see that day.

column22: My sister described this waterfall to me so many times, I thought I would know exactly what to expect when I at last saw it for myself. The reality, however, is far more beautiful than I had ever imagined.
Josselin─whose name this spire bears─was a legendary captain from the Wood Wailers' early days. Whenever my bow falters, I need only remind myself that my forebears fight in spirit by my side.
Walking ones may think this one's home is small, but this one has biggest home of all! The forest itself is this one's home! What does walking one think of that?
I can't talk to those sylphs. Yes, they scare me a little. Look, they aren't like you and me, you'd be talkin' to them and they'll just start...messin' with you.

It <Emphasis>is</Emphasis> a sight to gladden the heart, isn't it? A garden to exalt the Twelve is a daunting task indeed, and ever do I strive. But sometimes─sometimes, I simply enjoy the beauty we have wrought.

I feel truly privileged to be involved in the restoration of the Sanctum. Returning each masterpiece to its original glory is like glimpsing into the mind of the artisan from whose hands it was wrought.

Of late, more and more people are being joined here in the Ceremony of Eternal Bonding. Seeing newly bound couples come out of the chapel with happiness writ upon their faces never fails to set my heart aflutter!
column23: <sigh> When will <Emphasis>my</Emphasis> turn come, I wonder...

column22: Buscarron might not pay his help much, but he treats us with respect. After growin' up in the company of brigands, that's more than enough for me.
Planning on taking a jaunt around Rootslake, are we? Well, do take care and enjoy yourself. I shall see you when you return─rather, <Emphasis>if</Emphasis> you return.
Never doubt that Camp Tranquil has a powerful protector in the Sixth Spear. You have heard of the prowess of Captain Landenel, of that I am certain.
Happenings at Takers' Rot and Redbelly Hive, the latest rumors concerning Urth's Fount... Why, if I have to write another report, my arm is going to fall clear off!
Antelope and dormice abound in these parts, but we must be careful not to hunt more than befits our need. What the forest gives, it can just as easily take away.
My dad's off hunting, and I'm bored, bored, boooooored! Isn't there anything fun to do around here?
This keep was built by the Amdapori, a people whose civilization flourished during the Fifth Astral Era. I wonder how they would feel if they learned that the place has become a haven for cultists.

Fallgourd Float's famed for its fragrant teas and warm hospitality. With such comforts at their disposal, wayfarers oft find that they're in no great hurry to resume their journey and face the perils of the road.
They call this place Alder Springs. Do you see the trees around you? We must never forget that this is <Emphasis>their</Emphasis> home, and that we reside here only by their sanction.

Cork? Why, one uses it as a stopper, very useful for meeker sorts of potions.
...Oh, the <Emphasis>Bobbing</Emphasis> Cork! Yes, it rafts upon Fallgourd Float. Why? Well, lakes need no clearing but forests do, or so they tell me.

Gold in the hills, gold in me purse～♪
The eatin's out here ain't much, but me wife's cookin's that much the worse～♪
Hammering away night and day has my arms achy and my tummy rumbly! Sometimes the weight of my pick is simply too much to bear. Then I turn my thoughts to my sick mum at home...
There's gold in these here hills─I can feel it in me bones. It called me here from Ul'dah, and you can bet I ain't goin' back home till I've mined meself a fortune.
The Elder Seedseer has placed great store in you adventurers. I pray that you will reward her faith by reaching out to aid the people of Gridania.
When I look at her, I feel as though I've come home. I can think of no other way to express it.
Beyond this gate lies Sorrel Haven. A “haven” indeed...for some of the most fearsome beasts you're ever like to lay eyes on. Passage will be granted only to those who can see to their own safety.
Were I to substitute the aether value in accordance with the professor's law of conversion, that would produce a theoretical limit of ten score five and fifty...or should there be no limit?
column23: ...Oh! I didn't notice you there, so utterly engrossed was I in my calculations. Lest you wonder, I am a student of the esteemed Professor Lamberteint, the leading authority in the field of... <sigh> You weren't wondering at all, were you?

column22: Hell-o, <If(PlayerParameter(4))>beautiful<Else/>handsome</If>! Why, this <Emphasis>is</Emphasis> impressive! All this must be the work of Fufucha and the Botanists' Guild. I wonder if it's worth the bother to present myself there during my stay?
Welcome to the Aurum Vale. If you've come seeking a fortune, I advise you to turn straight around. These fumes may glitter, but no gold awaits here─only death and suffering.
An aesthete is by nature cruel, because crude things offend our nature and there <Emphasis>will</Emphasis> be so much crudeness. And oh, won't someone throw a pearl in my wine?
Gegeroon work for Memeroon. Always many, many works. Gegeroon make many, many shinies!
I haven't had many visitors out here of late. Did you come to danger near Poor Maid's Mill? An unfortunate name for an unfortunate place, that.
column23: It was once a lively hub for loggers, till they were all killed off by wild beasts. Only their impoverished widows were left behind. Not quite sure why they came to be called maids, though...

column22: I fear that convalescence has blunted my mind even as it knits together my wounded body. I know myself to be fortunate, for I have met others here who see kobolds around every corner, but I must not forget that my war goes on.
Welcome to the Warmwine Sanitorium. Here, we treat the wounded from the front with healing waters from the very womb of the earth, and heated wine redolent with spices.

Remember Carteneau, I say! I was there under the Maelstrom standard and for every drop of my blood, the Garleans paid double! The Twelve willing, I'll fight again, and if I fall? Why, I'll see my comrades from the Flats again!

That...that <Emphasis>boom</Emphasis> of the magitek armor. Can't stop hearing it...see how my hand shakes so? Used to be that I'd pinch myself on my face, for sure and certain. Least I'm clear of that.

That <Emphasis>smarts</Emphasis>! The Twelve spit in my eye if I lie, that smarts like Ifrit himself skewered me with a stick of how-do-ye-do! I'd like to git me hands on that Garlean what mistook me for his pincushion...
Tra-la-la, I do believe this is just right! Not too hot, not too cold.
I came here by way of the Wanderer's Palace. Oh, how you would love it there, a daring adventurer like you! There are automata contrived into the very walls...dozens of secret rooms there must be.
Don't you go coddlin' any ideas of gold and glory─nuthin' hale will rise from that bed. The Wanderer's Palace is more a tomb than a trove.
Who in the seven hells are ye? Ye stand on the front lines of outer La Noscea. If yer not ready to fight for yer bloody life, ye'd best march right back to wherever ye came from.
I jus' stands here and looks for the supply balloon. 'Tain't the food what's short but the fresh meat. Meat's important to a body on account of we being made of it or sumfin'.

Arrr, it's been years since I gave up piratin' to serve an honest life in the Maelstrom. But between you an' me, there are still days when I can hear the sea callin' me home. An' I reckon I'm not the only one, aye.
Adventurer! When you're tired of culling birds and moles, come hunt the sandworm with us!
We must think <Emphasis>beyond</Emphasis> our ken! If you have ideas, bring them to me, the next nunh of Forgotten Springs─no matter how peculiar they seem.

Oh, but it does make sense, it really does! If you come by oxcart, it feels like half a malm, and like two malms if you come on foot. So to a minotaur it would be exactly a malm! 
Actually, now that I've said it...hm.
